{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3651464,"name":"Goktug Yildiz","username":"goktugyldz","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/bc79bd/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-12T06:45:13.051Z","cooked":"

I want to learn how to code a swerve drive but the documentation of wpilib I don’t find it that useful how can I learn to code a swerve drive without any library?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-06-12T06:45:13.051Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":187,"readers_count":186,"score":87.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":503078,"topic_slug":"about-swerve-drive-coding","display_username":"Goktug Yildiz","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60182,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/about-swerve-drive-coding/503078/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3651472,"name":"Jeffrey Davis","username":"Practicality","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/practicality/{size}/208492_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-12T07:29:23.783Z","cooked":"

Well the wpilib has a lot of things to simplify the process but I can give you broad overview of the procedure/challenges you need to solve to make this happen.

  1. Communicate with all your hardware. You need to be able to read a heading on your gyro, reset your gyro, read a heading on each steering encoder and set a speed or power on each steering motor and each drive motor.
  2. Keep track of each swerve modules’ direction and speed.
  3. Translate back and forth between the 4 module direction/speeds and the direction/speed of the robot (including rotation)
  4. Translate back and forth between driver input (joystick or controller directions) and a relative chassis speed and then use that and what you did in step 3 to give commands to each module and ultimately each motor.

Steps 1 and 2 are pretty easy if you use an absolute encoder. All you need to do is set each module so 0 is straight forward (or set an offset to make 0 be forward) and then you can use the encoder value to find each wheel angle.

Steps 3 and 4 have prebuilt classes in wpilib that do this for you. If you don’t want to use anyone else’s classes you’re going to need to learn some trigonometry. It’s not super complicated, you’re just translating angles and speeds (AKA vectors) but I think reinventing the wheel here isn’t going to be much benefit. I would recommend at least reading/understanding what the wpi classes are doing before attempting my own version.

That’s pretty much it. There’s a lot of details for tuning motor speeds and feedforward values and such, but that’s really a seperate topic and you can go as deep or as shallow in that topic as you want. You can make a perfectly good swerve drive by just applying % power to you drive motors (and turn motors) based on the intended vectors you find.

I wrote this over Christmas break in 2019, so it’s a bit dated. But we used it to train our senior programming students on how to write a swerve drive system from scratch in 2020 and 2022.

4907 ThunderStamps Swerve Drive.pdf (1.2 MB)

Modern implementations like YAGSL and CTRE’s swerve generator use a lot of built-in functions inside of WPILib, but the above document was written before those tools were widely available. It does everything from scratch.

If nothing else, it gives you a good foundation of how all the math works.
